Today we welcomed back all our Classified Staff with the first of a two-day Professional Development orientation. In addition to a special welcome back message from our Assistant Superintendent of Education Services and some site-specific development sessions, our staff participated in a number of breakout activities facilitated by Keynote Speaker, Dominique Smith, emphasizing the social and emotional importance of not only our students and families but also of the support systems around them (i.e. our staff). Smith reminded our staff that "every kid is one caring adult away from being a success story" and provided some essential tools and practices for maintaining that sentiment.

We welcome back all our staff and, though the start of the school year is different from usual, our overall goal always remains constant as we strive to provide an educational environment where all our students can succeed and where their dreams can become a reality.

Yesterday, our county public health officer ordered that schools remain closed as a result of the COVID-19 epidemic. As a result, the Patterson Joint Unified School District will be postponing the start of school until September 8th, the day after Labor Day. We hope that by this time, schools in Stanislaus County will be able to reopen at full capacity. We are also hosting an informational WebEx meeting for all families on Wednesday, July 22 at 6 p.m. The WebEx link will be included in your PeachJar communication.

Sincerely,
Dr. Philip M. Alfano

July 14, 2020

Dear Parents:
Yesterday, our county public health officer ordered that schools remain closed as a result of the COVID-19 epidemic. As a result, the Patterson Joint Unified School District will be postponing the start of school until September 8th, the day after Labor Day. We hope that by this time, schools in Stanislaus County will be able to reopen at full capacity. If we are unable to open by September, our staff is prepared to continue providing distance learning or a hybrid model of instruction for our students.
A school reopening mailer with more details will be sent to all families this weekend. This information will also be posted to our website, and distributed through PeachJar later today.
We are also hosting an informational WebEx meeting for all families on Wednesday, July 22 at 6 p.m. The WebEx link will be included in your PeachJar communication.
As always, our best wishes to you and your family. Please stay healthy and safe during these difficult times.
Sincerely,
Dr. Philip M. Alfano
Superintendent

post_text: After school today, we received a report of a gun being brandished from a moving vehicle near Creekside Middle School. The weapon was not discharged. Students participating in after school activities at Creekside were kept indoors until the incident was resolved. We want to take this opportunity to thank everyone for their quick response to this dangerous situation.

Additionally, each grade level was challenged to bring 100 toiletry items to donate to Host House. With a grand total of 2,469 items collected, the totals were as follows:

Kinder - 657 toothbrushes
1st - 161 toothpaste tubes
2nd - 148 shampoo bottles
3rd - 474 bars of soap
4th 148 hand sanitizer bottles
5th - 241 deodorant sticks
Staff - 640 feminine products

Great job to Apricot Valley for not only finding unique ways to celebrate your education but also providing a service-learning opportunity for students and staff by providing hundreds of necessary items to those in need.

December 7, 2019 at 12:09 AM ·

What an honor it was to host the National Association of Publicly Funded Truck Driving Schools Regional Conference. Twenty attendees from around the United States were treated to a wide array of guest speakers and also a tour of the Patterson High School Logistics program along with a tour of the Restoration Hardware distribution center. The highlight of the conference was a question and answer session with former and current students of the high school trucking program who shared life changing and personal stories that had everyone captivated. We are pleased to announce three Mental Health First Aid training sessions open to all Patterson community members and partners. These are three sessions of the same training, so you would only need to attend one session to complete the training. For all the details and to register, view the full training invitation online at bit.ly/PJUSDMHFA.

Mental Health First Aid teaches you how to identify, understand and respond to signs of mental illnesses and substance use disorders. This 8-hour training gives you the skills you need to reach out and provide initial support to someone who may be developing a mental health or substance use problem and help connect them to the appropriate care. There are two versions of this training: One is the standard Mental Health First Aid, which applies to adults. The other is Youth Mental Health First Aid, which is specifically tailored for adults who support youth.

Each Mind Matters Day 5: Talk with a Friend, Ask for Help

Did you know that good friends are good for your health? Share your dreams, talk about things that stress you out and let your friends know you care about them. Doing this will help boost confidence and help us cope with the ups and downs of life.

Even when we follow all of the self-care tips shared this week, there will be times where we just need some extra help… and that’s perfectly okay! If you need help, ask for help. If a friend or someone you know needs help, ask them if you can help or find someone who can. Sometimes that just means sitting with someone who is sad and sometimes it means finding an adult to help when things are really bad. No matter what’s happening, things do get better and everything is easier when you connect with other people.

For more information visit: eachmindmatters.org/spw2019/.

Each Mind Matters Day 4: Be Mindful and Laugh

Do you want to hear two short jokes and a long joke? Joke, joke, joooooooooooooke. Okay, so maybe you didn’t laugh at that one, but did you know that laughter can improve your mood even if you fake laugh? Laughter increases the release of “feel good” chemicals in the brain and can relax your body.

Sometimes it can be hard to pay attention when someone is talking to you. Our minds may be full of other thoughts and distractions. Did you know that taking a moment to observe things around us, can help boost focus and help our mind stress less?

For more information visit: eachmindmatters.org/spw2019/.

Each Mind Matters Day 3: Time Off (Relax, Reset, Unplug)

Today’s message is all about taking time off. As nice as it would be, we can’t always take long vacations or avoid school and other work. But even small breaks can be helpful in boosting your mood and relieving stress. Set aside some time each week to not think about school or other work. Give yourself time away from your cell phone or video games and spend time together with people you enjoy. If something is stressing you out, write it down and put the note somewhere you will see it later. Doing this can help you enjoy the time off you’ve scheduled for yourself.

For more information visit: eachmindmatters.org/spw2019/.

Each Mind Matters Day 2: Exercise and Get Outside

People tell us all the time that we should get lots of exercise, but sometimes we just feel like sitting on the couch. But did you know that getting exercise actually gives you energy? Exercising at least three days every week will also decrease stress and improve happiness. Getting active outdoors is even better! Nature and sunlight can actually improve our mood and boost focus. So get out there and have fun to take care of yourself!

Each Mind Matters Day 1: Nutrition and Sleep

Did you know your mind needs good nutrition and sleep to stay healthy, just like the rest of your body? Fruit and vegetables may not be your favorite things to eat, but these provide important fuel to help keep you healthy, happy and ready to learn. Find your favorite fruits and vegetables and eat more of those than any other types of food in your meals. Drink lots of water every day and reach for water when you feel thirsty.

Did you also know that going to bed at the same time every night can help you fall asleep faster and get better sleep? Everyone should get at least 7-9 hours of sleep each night. Avoid screen time 30 minutes before bedtime and shut off your cell phones and video games through the night. Good sleep will help you feel happy and energetic throughout the day, so remember to keep a good sleep schedule every night!

For more information visit: eachmindmatters.org/spw2019/.
